topics.title: Soldering Resistor Leads
topics.description: Connecting joints with solder and trimming leads.
topics.coverage_text:
Hey everybody, it's Clark at Amplified Parts and we are here to talk about prototyping circuit boards today.
One of the easiest ways to start is with a breadboard.
This is something that you don't have to solder on to.
We sell these, they're very nice, there's an adhesive back on it.
And you know, the great thing about this is it's really good to do in the early stages of any kind of prototyping.
We also sell zip wire, this is basically like a jumper for a breadboard.

topics.title: Bridging Component Leads
topics.description: Conveniently connecting multiple components using a single lead.
topics.coverage_text:
And what's great about this, we have male to male, we have female to male, we have female to female.
So there's all kinds of different ways that you can lengthen and help design your stuff that much easier.
Now one of the things that we've noticed a lot of people have been doing lately is Arduino, and this is great for that type of application.
If you've never used a breadboard before, we have a Junior Genius Kit that is really great.
It's got simple designs, more complicated designs, and it's a really good gift idea if you're thinking about getting for the Virginine Builder in your life.
Breadboards aren't really for final design, they're for the prototyping stage, this is what we're talking about now.
We have a solderable breadboard and a non-solderable breadboard.

topics.title: Stripboard and Padboards
topics.description: Using stripboard and padboard for designing and building circuits.
topics.coverage_text:
So when you're in your design stage, if you find something you really like on this one, it can be transferred to this and soldered in a more permanent kind of manner.
Once you get past the breadboard stage, if you want it to be a little more permanent, you could use either a stripboard or a padboard.
These can be used in DIY pedal builds, and they're a great place to, once you've kind of begun your process of designing with the breadboard, you can move on to this and it makes it a little more permanent.
We're going to cut to a video close-up that will show you some of the differences between soldering on a padboard and a stripboard, so you can get an idea of which one might work for you better.
Padboard is a general purpose circuit board with a through-hole design and one pad per hole.
The padboard we sell is double-sided, with square pads every fifth hole, making it easy to align components and keep track of spacing.
We're going to add a few resistors to the board and make some connections.
First, take a resistor and bend the component leads at 90 degrees. If available, a lead bender can be used.
Next, insert the leads through the holes.
Hold the resistor down and flip the board over.

topics.title: Standoffs and Enclosures
topics.description: Using standoffs to prevent shorting and grounding issues in enclosures.
topics.coverage_text:
Bend the lead slightly outward to provide tension to hold the component in place.
Repeat the process with another resistor, with one of the leads going through a hole adjacent to the other resistor's lead.
When soldering, it's helpful to place the padboard on a flat surface with the leads facing up.
Apply solder to both neighboring pads one at a time.
A screwdriver tip is better than a conical tip for making solid contact with both the pad and the component lead.
To connect the joints, touch the soldering iron between the pads, making contact with both solder joints.
Apply more solder to both pads.
After the joints are soldered properly, we are going to trim the leads, but first we will inspect the joint to make sure we have a proper connection.

topics.title: Conclusion and Social Media Links
topics.description: Summary of the video and links to social media platforms.
topics.coverage_text:
Once we are sure the connection has been soldered properly, we can trim the leads.
We are going to repeat the process with another resistor.
It's possible to connect components that are not adjacent to one another.
We will do this with the remaining two resistor leads.
We bend one of the leads in the direction of the other lead and flatten it to the board, ensuring that it makes contact with the other lead.
Now we will solder the bent lead at the location where it is going through the board.
Once the bent lead is soldered in place at the first joint, trim the end of it so that it does not extend beyond the other component's pad to prevent excessive bridging.
Now we will solder the two leads to the pad where they meet.
